Ratings.comment: Great lecturer, super sweet and greatly helped with my understanding of coding (I had minimal experience before the class, the instructor offered a great foundation.)
Dr. Vines was very kind and genuinely cared for students success. The class is easy if you read the rubrics and turn in things on time.

Dr. Vines was one of the nicest instructors I've had. She was very helpful in her office hours and made a mandatory course I wasn't fond of a lot more enjoyable. I highly recommend taking the FE courses with her.
So strict on Graphic Assignments. Even my worst enemy in my life, I will not recommend him to take her class
Bad at teaching

She treats her students as if they are still in high school. She berates anyone who mutters a word in her class. High ego and does not care about the material she is "teaching". Choose anyone else for your own good.

Very condescending, very much held the vibe of "I am a doctor, and I am better than you" blatantly disrespected and talked down to a student with autism, blatantly disregarding them.  She would publicly embarrass you in front of the class if you talked while she was speaking even at a whisper level to your group mates.

Easily the best GTA I have had in my time at OSU. Send's almost daily messages reminding students of homework, offers amazing help in office hours, provides meaningful and understandable examples in recitations. If I had a GTA like Boden in every class, I would have absolutely nothing to worry about. Cannot express enough how awesome he is.

Boden is an absolute gem! Easily my favorite instructor at OSU!! He explains things clearly and is super helpful. Honestly he makes a tough semester somewhat enjoyable. I only wish I could have him for every class!

I had Boden as my physics tutor, and he really turned things around for me. I wish I had started tutoring with him from the beginning of the semester. He's a nice guy, and the way he explains things is super clear and helpful. Honestly, he should be teaching physics!
Had him for ME3751 and was 1000x better then the actual professor
I was struggling with dynamics this semester and Boden spent his own time to tutor me for free! he knows his stuff back to front and was really helpful! my first midterm went very well
Super duper helpful! THIS DUDE IS THE GOAT!!!
He understands the course materials extremely well, and on top of that, he knows how to be a good instructor

Had him as a tutor for physics. This guy should be a real professor, cause he did 100X better than my prof! He made difficult concepts look like a piece of cake. Have always enjoyed the way he teaches. It is like watching a stand-up comedy lol

Each student paid ≈$90 for the software we use in class. 200 students * $90 is $18000 per class. She taught 3 classes, meaning this semester alone, she made ≈$54,000 off of her students. She is truly an inspiration to me, as I now wish to become a professor for a required class so that I too can make a ton of money off of my students.

Sandy is funny, passionate, and easy to understand. Although the course content is fairly simple, I would definitely recommend attending classes and paying attention somewhat to the textbook. She provides ample examples in class and the homeworks are just like the exams which are on excel.

Very helpful, wants to make sure you understand. Never makes you feel dumb for asking a question. Exams were fair and lined up with the HW / in-class activities. She had required textbook reading assignments, and they were tedious and annoying, they barely lined up with the lecture content. The textbook and lecture felt like two different classes.

Dr. Furterer was an excellent professor. She always wanted to help you learn and was easily available outside of class. The material is incredibly easy. The exams were open-note and like the homework. The homework is simple and you have many attempts. Good class with a lot in it! Don't skip, though, even if it's boring, you'll regret it.

Her lectures were great. I went the whole semester without opening the book because she explained everything so good that I didn't need to. The exams are in person and open book/notes AND you can ask questions to her or the TA and they will guide you through the problem. Overall amazing professor!
Looks like a pencil

Terrible teacher that has no mercy at all , Won't accept late hw / homework that ain't latex form , He will deadass give you a Zero on homework instead of taking partial credit off, That is just inhumane.Harsh grader , Who does not  care about students grade.

He is a very passionate lecturer. But, the course was taught from a very math oriented pov and I think I still do not know anything about course even though I got an A. There is no broader sense given to why we are maniopulating a bunch of matrices and what we want to achieve. Definitely not useful froma ny actual practical learning

Serrani's lectures are great and he is a very nice person. Besides being an expert, he was always very enthusiastic, which is very important in a theoretical class like this. His class was challenging, but he teaches all you need to understand and do well in the exams. Do not expect a lot of numerical examples.
Passionate teacher, well-prepared lectures.

Serrani is an amazing teacher.  The best teacher I have had in OSU.  Even though his classes are though, you leave learning a lot.  Also, take advantage of the office hours, he will not judge you and he is very helpful.

He is feeling it! The way he is teaching the famous "change of basis" topic is awesome :) He is a real gentleman and a wise man. You may see Serrani at one of the floors of SEL while he is taking a book from the shelves any time. He has a big heart; even you perform an act that is disrespectful, he forgets it. He remembers good things :)
Nice style of teaching. Gets involved but the assignments are really tough.

Serrani is a great lecturer.  If you're anything like me, half the battle in class is keeping your focus on the words being said.  Serrani will draw you in.  It's true that he was challenging, but this is acceptable when the teacher gives you all the knowledge needed to perform well.
Awesome Prof. Exciting lectures, clear presentation, and sets you up to tackle his challenges. If you want to learn, take his class. If you want to float, don't.

Serrani is the kind of teacher that pulls you into learning with his enthusiasm.  He has a loud and audible voice that constantly has your attention.  His 551 was organized and paced very well.  His assignments were very fair in length and difficulty.  The tests were based off of homeworks directly and weren't that bad.

Dr Serrani did a much better job in 315/52 last year, but he is still one of my favorite instructors. He is extremely challenging, and exams are very hard, but you get a good grade if you are willing to work hard. I just wished he used the blackboard instead of PowerPoint presentations. He is a very cool person.

Dr. Serrani is a true expert in his field. He knows his stuff really well and he'll answer any question you ask him without difficulty. He is by no means easy and truly challenges you. If you follow his lectures and do the homeworks you will really learn. But if you just want to sit on your ass and do no work, then look elsewhere.

I took 351/2 with Dr. Serrani. He may not be the easiest instructor on campus, but he is certainly the instructor you want to take when you can take him. He has a great sense of humor, extremely helpful during office hours, knowledgeable, and replies emails quickly. He has a great job spirit. He is absolutely the most pleasant instructor I had.

One of the few instructors who thinks it's better to give students confidence rather than breaking them down. He is challenging, yet rational, reasonable, kind, fun, knowledgeable, and down to earth. Office hours are wonderful! He is a big fan of soccer, so u better love Juventus; otherwise he will kick u out of his office. hates Ac, Inter & Fioren

Dr. Serrani works hard to give students an intuitive understanding of the material.  He doesn't bore you with endless proofs but rather illustrates the principles with mech or elec examples.  He is very helpful during office hours as well.  My only complaint is that there is still a leap of understanding between lecture and homework problems.
JFL is the man! Entertaining lectures!

I loved Professor Lee. He cares more that you understand the material and the grade is secondary. His lectures are very student involved (A couple of us lectured for him in front of the class) and he makes funny deprecating jokes. Exams are take-home and he works through them in class before they are due. I learned a lot from his teachings!

He uses a lot of self deprecating humor in class. This is the hardest class I have ever taken. He makes it seem like he's going to curve the final because that's what he did for the midterms and then he didn't, which was annoying.

A master of the material. He is very good with the rigors of the maths and the explanation of the physics behind boundary value problems. I highly recommend his courses if you really want to learn something about the deep, underlying principles of Maxwell's equations.
Probably worst class I've ever taken. Combination of Lee's horribly unclear teaching, boring material, and his pompous attitude i hated every minute of this class

His teaching material helps a lot. I took a similar class two years ago and I found out his material has been a lot more organized and helpful. You could learn a lot from his class once you really try to understand computational EM.

Skipped 25% of the lectures, never replied his emails, and was never in his office during his office hours. Extremely arrogant, rude, impolite and offensive. He joked the first half of the quarter, but then accused us of being dumb and lazy. Void him at any cost. He is a disgrace to EM program at OSU. He should leave OSU immediately!
This professor is arrogant,ruthless, and shamelss. He doesn't care about the student accept for trying to make a big name for himself. Prof. John Voulakis should fire him immediately.
He is really good in explaining physics and math behind electromagnetics

Jin-Fa is really a math professor in diquise! Loves proving vector calc. Of course the class was hard, its electromagnetics! Nevertheless he was sent from the hevans above-he really wants you understand the concept! "Don't worry about your grade, you will do good". Failed midterms and final, but still got a B+. Like I said, he was sent from above!

Crazy, ruthless, and confusing, but very hilarious! Material before 1st midterm a repeat of Physics 132, but then it picks up and gets complicated. Grading is very generous. As long as you write the correct equations on test/homework, you will get an A!

What a jerk.  He was goofy/funny early on when the material was easy, but once there is anything you don't understand you are in trouble.  Can barely understand his english.  "Let me wepeat one more time..."  he sucks.  Refuses to do example pro
He has been the lecturer of ECE2050 for 30 years. Once you follow with him all the lectures, notes, and homework a you will know why OSU didn't change him.

Has a policy in the syllabus stating that he can fail students at will even if they would have passed the class based on the numerical values that he has expressed on the syllabus and on each individual assignment.

Prof. Bradley Clymer is highly knowledgeable and arguably the best for introducing signals and systems. His teaching style might be challenging for some students, so be prepared to adapt. The material starts easy but becomes harder. Weekly homework assignments can be long and occasionally confusing, which I found particularly difficult.

This was my favorite class I've taken before.  Prof. Clymer was always very enthusiastic and also went over the material in a way that made it much easier to understand.  If you go to office hours and make an effort to get to know him, he will also try to get to know you.

One of the best professors at OSU. He cares about his students and makes a huge effort to communicate the material in a way that you will understand. Office hours were underutilized in my section but super helpful for the projects (they are long, start early!) I learned so much in this class and got to see many aspects of 5200 applied practically.

Very nice and passionate prof who is very helpful in office hours. Lectures were fast paced and I honestly didn't understand them until reviewing them. Gives good partial credit and gives great practice exams to review. He made a hard topic easier and you can do well if you take advantage of office hours and practice exams.

Very dry, old school style lectures. He focuses almost entirely on the procedural part of the problems so it feels like a math methods class. He will often show shortcuts that doesn't make sense to us yet. I felt because there was such little grounding, this style left me forgetting most of what he did shortly after but it's ok if you like signals

His lectures are very dry as he only goes over theoretical examples and never actually does example problems. He gives some other papers he has written as background info but it's hard to apply to what he is actually teaching. It's impossible to finish his tests on time, his lectures are just random info here and there. He can't teach well.

Prof Clymer is a great professor who is genuine when it comes to teaching. He is very helpful in his office hours, and takes time to make sure you truly understand what is going on in each problem. He also posts practice exams/previous exams for each midterm/final in the class, which makes preparing for tests much less painful than most classes.

I found it hard to rate him. He is EXTREMELY knowledgeable and smart, but I found it hard to learn from him. His lectures are done on-screen on a legal note pad and were sometimes hard to comprehend. He also writes really fast. He is super helpful and will give you as much help as you are willing to seek.
Dr. Clymer is a respectable professor, making the class educational but not too easy, all with some smoke and mirrors.

Awesome professor, been teaching this class for a long time so is very good at teaching it.
I ended up not going to lectures because his notes he uploads after class are so good. Lots of homework to help you master the material and prepare you well for exams. He also uploads multiple practice exams that are 100% practicing.

Amazing professor. Understands the material well and very good at conveying the right information. The homework is very straightforward and reinforces the things you learn in lecture. The problem sets and practice exams were extremely helpful for figuring out the material. His handwriting is very clear and he is very accessible outside class.

Dr. Clymer is the sweetest professor ever. He provides so many resources like video lectures, homework help videos, and practice exams with answers. You always know exactly what you'll be tested on. I wasn't a big fan of signals/systems, but Dr. Clymer was so passionate and positive that I enjoyed going to lecture and learning.

Professor Clymer is very organized with his notes, as well as with his Carmen page. He has all the lecture notes, lecture videos, homework assignments, and other relevant material easily accessible. The only critique I have is the homework is usually very difficult unless you watch the corresponding problem session video.

Bradley needs to give every other professor a lesson on how to organize course content and a Carmen page. Everything you need is perfectly organized on Carmen: video lectures, lecture notes, homeworks, exam prep, everything. Clymer can be dull during lecture but is so organized that the material is understandable. Super helpful in office hours.
He's OK, his lectures are boring. The in-class examples are ridiculously drawn out for no reason. It's hard to make Signals interesting though.

Not only is he a great instructor (that puts his lectures online so you can re-watch them) he is very lenient with his grading so you wont get punished massively for an algebra mistake. Just listen to him carefully, do the homework, and practice for the exams and this class will be a guaranteed A with him

It was such a rewarding experience to have him as a professor: Well-organized and dedicated professors who dies for success of students. His guidance through the lectures + projects, as well as career advice and mental support, mean a lot to me. He is one of the reasons why I am going to do PhD in Signal Processing & Medical Imaging.

Probably one of the most organized courses I have taken. All lectures are posted online via PDF and video. While the homeworks may be challenging, he posts practice videos of homework problems that are pretty helpful. In addition, he provides practice exams for each exam, which gives you a good idea of the difficulty of the exam.

Love Dr. H. Super friendly guy who clearly cares about students and their progress. Great course and lectures as well. Ohio State FEH classes are brutal but the instruction is top notch and Dr. H. is no exception. Be prepared to do a *lot* of hands-on assignments ("apps") which are not easy (better than FEH 1 though) and group work during class.

Dr. H was a great prof. Class had a lot of work, especially with the lab reports, so start early. He was a very caring and nice instructor, and had great knowledge of MATLAB and C. Overall, great prof.

I loved Dr. H, he genuinely cared about his students and all of the office hours available outside of class were extremely helpful. As a student who had never coded before, he made everything a very seamless progression, and everything was easy to understand and follow with the practice problems and homework. Highly recommend!
Probably one of the best professors I've had! Though it was his first time teaching, he knew the material well and kept the class engaged.

Professor El Hamahmy is amazing! Nne of my favorite professors, and genuinely cares about his students. Lectures are chill, you MATLAB, C/C++ as well as engineering fundamentals. There is a coding project instead of final. Weekly assignments, from lectures and from labs, lecture assignments are doable, but lab assignments take up the most time.

Dr. Hamahmy, better known as Dr. H has by far been the best professor I've had in college so far. He makes an effort to get to know every single one of his students of they let him. Another great thing is that he's always accessible for you to ask questions so his assignments aren't impossible if you make the effort to ask questions.

Maybe the best teacher I have ever had. A great personality along with a good understanding of MATLAB and how to teach it. The course uses a fair amount of things learned in ENG1181. It is very important that you work though homework and practice problems, because if you fall behind, you fall fast. Stay in contact with / see him outside of class.
Funny guy, I'd imagine not sure though. I dropped out my second day in the class because of some horrible smelling heffer #freepalestine

Gilat lectures well, his midterms were fair, his final was difficult, but he curved the class afterward. His office hours are helpful, and while he comes off as demeaning, he does not mean it. His homeworks are much harder than midterms, so it prepares you well for them. I think his bad rep is undeserved, people who show up and study do well.

AVOID. Take this class anywhere else, do not interact with Amos Gilat at all. Nice guy, sure, but not good teacher. Tests are 88 percent of the class, they are WAY harder than the homework, and no other opportunities for extra credit. Our final grade average was 55. THAT IS FAILING. If the average student fails your class, retire.

Bad lecturer and even worse at setting up a class. All combined, the entire class came down to how you did on exactly 16 problems. Nice enough if you meet him outside of class, but still won't help you much. He means well, but still avoid him if at all possible.

Gilat was one of the worst lecturers I've ever had. His lectures only include solving problems, with little explanations as to why we solve them. There are only 4 grades in the entire class: 6 quizzes, 2 midterms and the final (44%). Refuses to curve, even when the midterm avgs were below 65%. Exams are lengthy/hard, he doesn't care if you pass.

Amos has some of the worst lectures at OSU, very hard to understand and most of the concepts require you to learn from YouTube. The class consists of 3 exams worth 88% of your grade. This concept alone should make anyone want to run away. When someone asks a question in class they are belittled. Worst experience Ive ever had. Avoid at all costs.

Don't take his course. You will only be graded on quizzes, midterms, and the final. The quizzes are worth 12% of your grade, midterms are 44% and the final is 44%. He is incredibly rude and will get upset if you ask a question that he doesn't think is a "good" question. He hates repeating anything and expects everything to come easy to everyone.

Avoid by any means necessary. Its a hard class but his teaching method makes it 10 times harder. It is example after example with little to no explanation behind his problem solving strategy. The final is hard and worth 44% of your grade which is outrageous. Unfortunately the worst experience I've had at OSU.

Professor Gilat doesn't teach you any of the material. He expects you to learn it on your own and he does practice problems in class. This method of teaching may work for some people but it doesn't for me. He is available outside of class and will answer your "good" questions, but if you ask a "bad" question you will get made fun of.
Not a bad person, but he is ignorant and kinda dont care how you do.
Terrible and old lecturer, doesn't put anything online and it really isn't worth going to lecture or recitation. HW takes a good 10 hours a week. Exams are all open book and fairly simple however.

1181 is just a semester long hot mess. If you have never programmed before, the MATLAB is a little confusing. The class just isn't structured very well for practicing and getting good at programming. Also, it's an "inverted" class which means you just go a lot of stupid work at home, in addition to homework, and quizzes before every class.

Professor Gilat seems nice, but has no interest in this course, as he mentioned multiples times throughout the semester. Requires you to buy 2 of his awfully written textbooks, in which you will realize wont help you much for the 10+ hours of homework a week. Advice for incoming students: be prepared to learn this course on your own.
He is a nice guy. If you go to office hours, ask him questions. He is a bit condescending, but he will answer questions and he knows the material well.
He will refuse to help during his office hours. He says he doesn't have time for you because he's too busy writing his text books. Terrible professor.

Made everything seem easy in class then I would struggle on homework and midterms, often not knowing what ideas to apply. The examples in class were helpful but it would have helped if he taught it in a way that we would know what concepts to apply depending on the problem statement and given information.
Gilat was awful at explaining things, does not give equation sheet on tests

I wish he was more clear explaining what his mindset is in solving problems. He does nothing but do example problems in class, which I liked. I found this class is immensely difficult. Doesn't provide or let you make an equations sheet, so have fun memorizing tons of equations instead of actually studying. Just terrible.
Terrible. Goes over a few simple examples in class that do not prepare you well for the exams or homework, both are very difficult. Take this course with Dr. Mokashi if you have the chance.

This class was terrible. I dont think i learned one thing the entire semester. The material is so bad so it's hard to say how he is as a teacher. Lectures are pointless but his exams are really easy due to the open book policy. Homeworks were very hard and long, and only time I had a problem and went to his office he refused to help me out.

One of my favorite Professors I've ever had. He's funny in a monotone kind of way and cares a lot about his students. Taught MATLAB,C,C++ and even though I had no coding background I did very well. Make sure to not procrastinate or it will lead to long nights before the due date. He is the best animator using power point there is.
Awesome teacher, recommend his classes.

Despite having absolutely zero experience with coding myself, Ethan Joll did a great job at teaching both MATLAB and C/C++. Although there is a lot of homework, it prepares you for the material on the quizzes and tests. Ethan Joll was the best, and would answer any questions that people had.

Very nice teacher and always really understanding when it comes to needing extended deadlines or anything of the sort. I liked him so much I made sure to take the 1282H class he was taking next semester. He is very entertaining and easy to talk to and overall a really good person.

The start of the course with Onshape (CAD) was easy b/c of his good lectures and clear rubrics (make sure to look at them for everything, don't loose points for random stuff and ask if you are unsure). For the robot portion it was a difficult, but as long as you have a good team (hopefully some of your friends) I think you will really enjoy it!!
This guy is the goat!!! He is such a good guy, and he is always down to help any students. I would highly recommend any FEH or FE students to schedule with him if you can!!!

He is one of the new teachers on campus, but is a really cool guy once you start talking to him! Don't be afraid to ask questions or talk about any circumstances, he is very understanding. He isn't a hard professor, it is just that the course guidelines make it hard.

New to the scene and tries his best. While a bit monotone and bland at first, they really show emotion later as they settle in and can be humorous at times. While not knowledgeable about SolidWorks, they offer great professional advice and give good feedback. Great 8 AM class.

He was just alright. At the beginning when teaching Solid Works, the way he taught was kind of boring and he didn't seem enthusiastic about it. He did answer questions well whoever asked and tried to help every student. He's a pretty lenient grader, and he got better over the semester. He tried to be more funny and enthusiastic as time went on.

The lab segment of this class was brutal, but the lectures (the part Dr. Kramer was responsible for) were great. She gets everyone involved, gives great feedback, and both her and her TAs are highly available in and out of class and happy to help students. I actually enjoyed the software design project at the end of the class. Highly recommend.

Dr Kramer is great. Incredibly caring and very knowledgeable. Class itself is hard and that will be consistent for all sections, but Dr Kramer knows the course very well which was incredibly helpful. If you get the chance, I would highly recommend! Couldn't get a nicer, more genuine professor at OSU
She's so kind and really helpful to her students.

Professor Kramer is great. Class itself is pretty easy, although the lab component can be brutal sometimes. Good lecturer, genuinely cares about the students and is willing to help, and lots of hands-on projects and "application" assignments. No textbook required (but if taking Honors, a MATLAB textbook is recommended for the programming sections).
Really nice professor, understandable, and flexible with deadlines if you ask. Also can really be helpful for additional projects if needed.

Amazing professor, deeply motivated and wanted students to make sure they understood the content. He made lecture's extremely easy to understand the material and very helpful in office hours if you needed more help. Quizzes were extremely specific regarding content but manageable. Take his class if you can.

Chris is legit the best. It was an honor to have him as my lecturer, and he is the main reason I am pursuing a humanitarian engineering minor. I would give almost anything to have him as a prof again!!

Dr. Ratcliff is awesome. He truly cares about his students and although 1181 is just a ton of busywork he makes the work a lot more bearable. He is always willing to help on projects and makes an effort to take an interest in his students. Truly a goat professor!
Professor Ratcliff was an amazing professor and cared about his students. Directions and outlines are clear for grading.
Dr. Ratcliff is a great engineering professor. His 1182 class is much more fun and interesting than 1181. He is very helpful and a good professor to make connections with.

Dr. Ratcliff shows applications of engineering and make sure we understand not only the technical part of engineering, but also the ethical side of it. I haven't had anyone explain engineering to me in that way and I will apply his ideas in my career. He understand circumstances with deadlines and is my most approchable professor.

Dr.Ratcliff is a really good instructor for the FE courses. He cares about his students deeply, yet will get you prepared so you can do well on the assignments and tests. TA's do usually matter a bunch in making this course tolerable but Dr.Ratcliff is very good at making sure the TA's are doing their job. Very likeable guy too. Take him if u can!

If you have to take 1181, do it with Dr. Ratcliff. Absolutely amazing professor, despite some things he's unable to change about the course itself. He's a great guy and he understands that this is too much for 2 credit hours,  so he's very understanding in how he gives extensions. Talk to him after class if you can, he's a great conversationalist.

Dr. Ratcliff was definitely one of my favorite professors I've had at OSU. He always had personal stories that related to the material he was teaching us and he genuinely cared about helping every group excel with their engineering design process. I think the the class 1182 could be changed some to be less paper heavy but I enjoyed having him.

Great teacher. I had no coding experience and he taught it well. Make sure to participate in the class. He gave many extensions, and a lot of good advice. Honestly, he made me realize engineering was the right choice for me. Hands down amazing teacher and human being.

Very nice, respectful, and accommodating guy. Some of the assignments are rather difficult but with a group they're manageable (as long as your group is competent). I had a particularly nice group (though it was only 3 people) and we managed to do pretty well. Easily one of my favorite professors at OSU.

Dr. Ratclidd was a great professor and cares about his students. Beware this class is a weed-out. It's a lot of work and frustrating depending on the group you get. It is doable if you are willing to do the work your group slacks on. Definitely do not save work till the last minute or you won't do well. The class taught great engr skills though.

The class is tough and there is a lot of work, because it is a weed out course. There is a lot of group assignments and class applications that take a long time. But Professor Ratcliff is a great professor and is very understanding of delays and issues that occur. He is great at teaching the material and I would highly recommend taking his course.
He was great, the class went smoothly.

The best teacher Ive ever had. Hes such a great guy and he really cares about his students and their success. Although the content of his class is somewhat boring, he does all he can to make it interesting. His experiences outside the classroom involving engineering are invigorating and youll get to learn all about it.

Dr. Ratcliff was a great professor overall. Sometimes the lectures could drag, but that has to do with the content more than the professor himself. He is very easy to approach and ask questions, and continues to be a great resource. There was quite a bit of out of class work, but nothing unmanageable. He gives lots of time to do the work in class.

Prof. Ratcliff is a great professor stuck with a dull course. However, he really tries to engage with the class and encourages us to pursue engineering. I really enjoyed hearing about his experiences in the field. Also, he's always down to help you if you need it or explain things better.

Out of all your options hes the only one that can teach the class well. Hes super flexible about assignments, stressors, and just your life in general. That said this class is still busy work but he makes it doable. All you have to do is hope you have a good group and good TAs and you should be good for this class. Definitely would take him again

This class is difficult by inheritance, from the department, but you gotta take him as a professor. Literally the only guy that can actually teach this class and actually care for the students. Very flexible with assignments and understanding of everyone's circumstances. Clarifies any holes he finds with assignment instructions.
she‘s good

Genuinely cares about the students if you express effort in the class, the amount of work in the class is definitely on the higher side especially for a 2 credit hour class but get used to it, your going into engineering.

The lectures were sometimes hard to follow because of how fast she went, especially the lectures on MatLab. I feel she could've given instructions on certain assignments way better. She talked to the class like we were middle schoolers which was the most annoying part of the class. Overall, I've heard of better professors for this class.

Doesn't read student work. Nor provide thoughtful feedback. Relies upon flowchart-like, pre-programmed responses. Her focus on her career leaves little care for students, promoting exclusion over inclusion. Consistently tardy and full of excuses, she holds students to standards she fails to meet herself. Impersonal style; undervalues students.

Dr. Thomas is a good lecture and has a good concept of what she is teaching. Was always helpful when struggling with items in class and was understanding and cooperative with situations that were less than ideal. 1181 is a course loaded with busy work and attendance is mandatory by GPS but overall not a bad class. Just do the work you will succeed.
Great professors, Only one thing is you have to go to class, the check in is mandatory and with GPS, so you have to go to class room.
Has improved in teaching overtime

The class is pretty group project heavy, but she's very open and is willing to meet whenever possible. I'm not a very good coder in MATLAB but she made everything so easy and open that I was able to ace the exam with ease. 10/10!
Amazing, best professor I've had so far

Very fair and understanding professor. Course was boring but she attempted to make it entertaining and engaging. Have had for a few courses so far and couldn't recommend more. Grading isn't too harsh, and rubrics detail exactly how TAs will grade.

It's not Dr. Thomas's fault that the Fundamentals of Engineering sequence is so... well... not great. There is more work in this course than you'd expect for a two credit hour course, but I think that Dr. Thomas tries her best to make the dry lectures slides a little more interesting and gives fair feedback and help on projects if you ask.

I got lucky with a good group and amazing TA's. Prof. Thomas loves a little comedic relief, and she enjoys solving problems in MATLAB. She reads from the slides during lectures and most of her instructions are vague. Attending her Zoom office hours when learning MATLAB really benefitted me.
She was nice and entertaining. Class is an easy A.

Super energetic, loves to explain (and complain) about MATLAB. Works through all HW and assignments in her own time, so gives super helpful advice if only you ask questions. Lectures pretty quickly, but she makes things pretty easy to understand.
Epic swqag w amazing yuh skrrt teacher if i have to be frank. EE OO EE OO EE OO EE OO pulling out the preoffesor DSWAGGGG
She's a good professor who is trying as much as she can to work with students and help them succeed.

Jessica is very passionate about engineering and teaching students! She always made an effort to make class more interesting and keep students engaged. 1182 is a relatively easy class if you enjoy autocad, but be aware that you will be working on the final exam (group project) for the whole semester.

ENGR1182 is not a fun course, but I'll say Dr. Thomas did the absolute best she could with it. She was always prepared for class and kept it organized so the student knew what needed to be done before each class. She was always avaliable to answer questions and made sure her TAs were avaliable to help us as well. She did a great job in this course.
Professor Thomas does a good job of being available for clarification on assignments. Tries to make the class as interesting as possible and relate it to real-world experiences.

Do not understand why the reviews are bad. She was SO NICE and literally told you exactly what you needed to do to get an A and helped out with every assignment. I guess if your group is bad it might be hard, but don't blame it on her, blame your group.
Super nice professor. Very available and organized. Even went out of her way to help me with an interview project for another class. Highly recommend.

To be honest 1181 was a lot of busy work. Its an easy A though if you put the effort in. Professor Thomas is a pretty good lecturer and is readily available. Its a ridiculous workload for a 2 hour class. I think most of the bad reviews are from people unwilling to work to get an A. Guaranteed A if you have a semi-competent group and a work ethic.

Not sure why her ratings are so low. She was a fine professor, always willing to answer questions in detail and available outside of class. The department just has this class set up awfully, unclear assignments, odd layouts, etc. etc. Not her fault though.

Professor Thomas is a good professor, not sure why her ratings are so low. Shes helpful and easy to contact if you need something. Beware of ENGR1181 though, its extremely group heavy and so much homework. If you get a bad group you will be screwed! Blame the department for how the class is set up, professor Thomas is doing the best she can

It's unfortunate to see Dr.Sommerich with such low ratings. She's a wonderful person and learning from her is a prilvedge. Still, I think she needs to reevaluate the structure of her course. The exams were a bit confusing, and expectations aren't clear. Getting an A- and having a 94 is not great. Put in the effort and you'll do ok..

Agree with everything previously mentioned- lectures are very boring and slow. Overall grades are hidden all semester and you don't know what you're ending with until it's put in, furthermore an A starts at a 95%. Exams are difficult but doable.

I wanted to ignore the reviews of people bashing Dr.Sommerich. However, her grading scale is just terrible. You don't know your grade throughout the whole semester and the cut-off "+" grades at high precentages. Having a 94% but still ending at an A- really sucked. Her lectures are dry and questions on exams are confusing. Nice lady, bad class.

Horrible instructor, hidden grades with no opportunities to clarify rubrics that don't exist. Will not change grade seven if there was a mistake. Has open door office hours, but is never there. Sets her grading scale so harshly its unfair that an A is at least 95%, an A- is anything less than that. Does not give ample time for readings/assignments.

Terrible instructor, does not provide clear grading criteria and changes the rubric after the assignment was due. Will not explain why she takes off 0.39 of a point when asked and refuses to give back points when grading rubric was unclear/non-existent. Won't post grades, you never know where you stand in the class and gives about 2 days to do hw.

Overall grades hidden entire semester. Doesn't give exams back you have to go to office hours to see them, but you can't keep it. Grades pretty tough. Most boring lectures on planet earth (which is sad because the material has a chance to be interesting). Midterms were wordy. Seems like a nice lady, but she shouldn't be a professor... like at all.

I've taken about 30 classes so far at OSU, this one definitely put me to sleep the most. Dry material and a soft spoken lecturer makes a terrible combination. Tons of busy work, sporadic assignments, weird grading system, and everything in Carmen is out of 0 so idk what grade I have. Line up your schedule to take this class with the other professor
find someone else with personality disorder
Avoid her class if you can.

I've had her for 3 classes.  She can be really nice when she wants to, and then not so much other times.  BIG BIG BIG fan of "busy work", loves chapter summaries! Only class where I've gotten a 82.64 on a quiz.  Odd grading policies, but still manageable.  Kinda stuck taking some classes with her, just suck it up, cuz its gunna suck.

Hated the class. The material was easy the teacher was awful. Her tests had poor structure to them and required too much reading.  The first few weeks of class were useless. All the material is common sense.  She is not very friendly.

She sucks; a low talker, speaks too slow, puts the students to sleep all the time, has a horrible grading policy, is a very closed minded and stubborn individual. If you do poorly in a test, think that she graded not fairly, or even she miss interpreted what you wrote, than good luck talking her into changing anything. I would avoid her if I can
She grades hard, their is just 100 points in the class. You have to do 2 hours of reading and turn in a write up for 0.5 of a point!!!! I did not like this class.
stressful ! used to a an easy class but not anymore !

The classes is extremely dense with topics but he does a good job explaining them in a slow and easy enough manner.  The exams were graded harshly with a poor grading distribution. There were MCQ's worth about 3-4% of the paper, and a lot of open ended questions were based on topics that were a brief mention in class.

Dr. Subramoni wants his students to succeed but struggles with grading. Exam averages were 70s with no curve on the final grade, and homework is not leniently graded either. His "open door" office hours make scheduling difficult, and he's often unresponsive to emails. Meeting outside of class to get help can be nearly impossible.

Professor Subramoni is a nice guy. He's smart and obviously is well versed in OS, but he does just an OK job of teaching it. He relies heavily on the slides and his examples often cause more confusion. The homework and labs were reasonable and fair. Exams were graded harshly and mostly free response. I lost 3% of my final grade on a T/F question.
He definitely cared about his students and what he was teaching, but wasn't the best at conveying the topics.

Prof. Subramoni is a great lecturer and I really enjoyed his class. He didn't assign my section much homework (only 4 homework assignments and 1 lab) which was really nice. Although this can come to hurt you if you aren't prepared for his exams. The lecture material is quite dense but he does a good job of slowing down the pace of lectures.

Very funny and kind professor and a well-structured class. I think some of his lectures could be more concise. Oftentimes, doing the actual work was much easier than trying to figure it out through his lectures. However, he's extremely flexible and makes the class interesting.
Very down to earth guy, do your work in advance and pay attention in lectures. If you ever need any help, don't be afraid to reach out to him. He also always has a fresh lineup in class :D
Amazing! I'm so glad he was my introduction to Engineering

This class is so boring and the first half is like stuff that's so easy. He also just randomly will start talking about stuff for like 10 minutes in the middle of lecture. The projects and labs are kind of cool but lectures are just so boring and this whole class felt pointless. He is good at responding to emails though.

Great professor, very passionate and energetic person. There is a good deal of work outside of class and a lot of your grade is based off team work so being in a good team is helpful. Application problems relate to the exam and zybook readings relate to the quizzes.

Really knowledgeable prof, one of the most well-spoken people I've ever met. Can articulate ideas in various ways. This class is "2 credit hrs" but really it's like 4. A lot of outside work and group work along with zybooks (textbooks for class). Applications are most of your grades, and they typically are content heavy. Otherwise, a good class.

Professor Parris was clearly passionate about teaching engineering and wanted to see his students be successful. My only complaint is that he would take up so much of our working time by lecturing even though multiple times he received feedback that we wanted the lectures to be shorter. The lectures seemed very repetitive at times too.
Pretty much average. Can't complain about him but I wouldn't go out of my way to take him again.

Dr. Parris is not only a great teacher, but truly cares about his students and helping them succeed in all areas of life. This class had a lot of homework and A LOT of writing, but it was an educational experience and emulated working in an engineering team on a product. Make connection with him and he will be a great reference!

Dr. Parris was a very kind professor. His primary goal is to prepare his students for what life may be like in the workforce and in future classes. The class, however, is a lot of work. It is not necessarily his fault, but it should be noted. I took this class online, and that made it extremely dry. The class also does not teach programming well.

A really kind and fun professor who tries his best to make class fun. He truly cares about his students and works with you through any unforeseen circumstance you may have. The actual material isnt difficult but you should pay attention in lecture and lab so you can feel confident with it as it could be beneficial in the future for engineering.

Dr. Parris does a great job at teaching very textbook content that is given to him in a fun environment. He is very experienced in industry and will share his knowledge and stories throughout lecture. He also really cares about his students and is willing to make accommodations if needed. All around he keeps class fun and enjoyable!

Dr. Parris is an interesting guy and has a lot of relevant industry experience. He was also very flexible with deadlines when our entire team got sick one week. Unfortunately, he teaches a really boring and unnecessarily work-heavy class. If youre stuck taking 1181, hes a good choice overall.

Great professor, cares about his students and enjoys teaching. When it came time to respond to emails however, sheeeeeesh. I'm still waiting on a response back from over a semester ago. There was an incorrect grade I recieved and I can't get a response to get it fixed. But otherwise he is a great teacher.
Took this online. He would make time to meet with you outside of office hours all the time if needed. Genuinely wants to connect with students. The work was straightforward but expect to write a lot.

Dr. Parris is about the only part of this class that is enjoyable. He gives incredible and engaging lectures to help learn a ton of content in such a short amount of time. Very generous person and is really passionate about his work. Make sure to follow the rubric for every assignment, as it is all strictly graded according to it.

Dr. Parris is awesome! He is willing to help and is pretty fun to listen to. He comes up with good analogies from his career and life and connects it to the content. The class itself is a lot of work, and definitely worth more than 2 credit hours, so be prepared for lots of homework, projects, etc.

Great guy, just the class should be a 5 credit hour instead of a 2. Also, the rubrics and procedures are way too vague so the UTAs will love to take points for random stuff that doesn't make sense. Also, the rubrics don't make sense as minor errors can make your grade drop by 70% on an assignment. You will hate the UTAs and the work.

Such a great guy. When I was falling behind in learning MATLAB, he sat down with me for a few hours just to talk through it. So incredibly helpful. I ended up getting 100 on the coding exam as well as the final, solely from his teaching. Super nice, approachable, and just a great professor.

Engr1181 is so much work, but that isn't Dr. Parris' fault. He's one of the most compassionate professors I've had - he knows the class is hard and he wants to help his students. He also listens to feedback. When we told him that we weren't doing the (required) reading because it was too long, he shortened it to make it more accessible.
Paul cares about all of his student's learning and teaches in a fun and engaging way.

"A pointer
is a variable
that has as its value
the address
of another variable."
Great at teaching and super funny too. He made a difficult class the most fun one I've taken. Textbooks were offered, but I never bothered to read them since the same material was covered in class anyway.
Amazing guy. Genuinely funny and cares about the students.

Best instructor for this course; you'll definitely get an A if you submit all the work and it's done competently, but you'll have to pour in tons of hours outside of class to finish the assignments in the first place.

GOAT. Amazing lectures, super caring, funny, and understanding professor. Make sure you go to class, if you Fundamentals of Engineering is a hard set of courses, honors or not, so be prepared to do a LOT of homework. His lectures helped me a lot with understanding how to do homework. Very nice guy
goat
Good teacher, tells jokes during lectures to keep it entertaining

My only gripe with Professor Clingan was how hard it could be to hear him at time in the class especially if you sat further in the back. Overall, he was a wonderful teacher, note that the readings and paying attention in class are extremely beneficial especially if you have no background in computer languages.

Very fun lectures and labs, however, this is a LOT of work for a 2 credit hour class. None of it is exceptionally difficult, but you're at the mercy of the teammates that you are assigned. Paul is an incredible professor and makes the class very fun to get involved in, and my lab team became some of my good friends. Highly recommend his class

Paul was one of the kindest and most resourceful professors that I have had thus far at OSU. He truly cares about his students and makes the at times boring content more lively with his humor. He offers great advice and is willing to sit and help students with various assignments!
Clingan is a fantastic, funny, and caring professor, and while the course is very difficult as is, Clingan does his best to make it as manageable as possible.

I had Paul for the FEH Nano project and definitely would recommend him. He is super laidback and has an extremely dry sense of humor. He's pretty approachable and cares about his students. Even though he's not an expert in nanotechnology/microbiology, he does his best to help you through the project along with the TA's.

Paul made a class that I was scared to take fun and mostly not overwhelming, even though it was a lot of work. He is funny, kind, genuine, and considerate. He always checked in on students for questions, comments, and concerns, and he actually listened and provided help or solutions if there were any. Even online, he was a fantastic professor!

Paul is just an awesome guy. FEH is a tough class both semesters, but he cares about his students and does his best to help you succeed. I thought he had a great sense of humor, and he was always available when I needed help.

FEH is a demanding course. With that being said, none of the problems I had in the class were with Clingan. He is an amazing person who deeply cares about how each and every one of his students is doing in class. He has a ridiculous amount of office hours too. One problem is that sometimes he moves a little fast, but his other qualities redeem him

Paul Clingan is an excellent instructor. I highly recommend him for the first year honors engineering courses. Most of the instructors chosen by FEH are of high caliber, and Clingan is no exception. There will be a lot of homework, but if you pay attention and go to class you will learn a lot.
Awesome dude

Mr. Clingan is a great professor. He knows the class is a lot of work regardless of how it's taught, so he makes it as bearable as he can. He lectures for about half an hour at the start of lectures and the rest of the time is yours. If you have any issues, he will do anything within his power to fix them and genuinely seems to like teaching.
You must stay on top of all of the work to pass this class.
Great guys, willing to help you if you need it. I like his sense of humor, his jokes help make the tough project a little more bearable. TAs do most of the grading.
Really good lectures and very caring professors. He wants you to succeed

Very good and nice professor. He knows his stuff. Make sure to ask for help if you don't understand something and he will gladly explain. Lots of lab reports, but it's not Casale who teaches the lab, so to me that was almost like a separate class. I would take again, and hope I have more wonderful professors like this in the future.

Lectures are so boring and honestly kind of useless. Attendance is mandatory and graded. Really nice guy. U will not get ur grades back on assignments for significant periods of time. Class is honestly not hard but there is just a decent amount of work. If u do the work u get an A.
Casale helped my team figure out their issues and it really helped us come up with a cool prototype

When our group approached him about an issue with one of our members he barely helped. Also avoid this class at all costs. I'm not even an engineering major idk how I ended up in this class. This will be the single hardest class you will take in all of college. Some people think he's a good professor. Different experience I guess.

Dr.Casale is really a great professor. His online section can be a bit shaky, but that is not his fault. This course is a lot of work, and he does his best with offering a crazy amount of opportunities for you to do well. If you put in the effort, you will do well negative reviews are for those who didn't try. Cares deeply about his students.
A great professor who genuinely cares about his students and wants them to succeed. Professor Casale is easy to talk to and willing to help. I would definitely recommend taking a class with him.
Great teacher. Lots of homework, but that's because of the course not him. The final project really helped the grade.
avoid this class
He's a really nice guy and helps out whenever you ask.
Not the best lecturer, but understanding, kind, and respected.
Incredible caring, very helpful and respectful. Genuinely wants every student to get an A and will help as much as needed.

Dr. Casale is a caring, intelligent, and extremely knowledgeable professor. Unfortunately, due to personal reasons I couldn't complete the class. However, if I could, I'd pass with an easy A. Sure there's a lot of assignments, lots of "busy work," but it's plenty of easy grades to pass with an A. If you can't pass, it's on you.

Aside from the group projects, I loved the class and loved Dr. Casale. He is a very interesting person and always tried to give a personal example of a concept covered in class, such as presentations that he had to give for his work, or papers he had to write before he was a professor. Definitely recommend, just be ready to work in groups a lot.

Dr. Casale is a cool guy, and he is very passionate about his job! He makes the class less stressful and is really chill when it comes to projects and presentations. He is so kind and loves to interact with students. I wish I could have taken this class with him in person, he seems like such an amazing professor who would be even better in person!

Casale is the BEST professor. He is genuinely one of the kindest profs I've ever had and I would take his class 50 times over. The setup of ENGR1181 leaves you with a lottttt of assignments, but he does his best to help you and make them manageable. If you're taking him, stick with it!! You won't regret it.

Dr. Casale has definitely been my favorite professor so far. He was a big heart and cares about all his students equally. He truly wants you to succeed and will gladly help you. Lectures are not the most engaging but that's more on the course material. His background experience allows good feedback and ideas. 11/10!

A very kind professor who cares about you succeeding in the class. Group had difficulties turning in an assignment and ended up turning it in late. Had a conversation with him and he was very understanding and waived the late penalty.
Dr. Casale is a great professor. He is so helpful and he actually cares about his students. You wont regret taking his class. He is the kindest professor around!

I took the Montaña de Luz service learning class to Honduras with Dr. Casale. The whole class became really close on the trip and I couldn't have asked for a better leader. If you have the opportunity to take Dr. Casale for any class, do it. He really cares and you will have a new favorite professor.

I took ENGR 1300, would often come to class unprepared and would sometimes end class after 10 minutes for work time. I felt I could do the entire class online asynchronous and still get an A. Other than never responding to emails, the content is outlined well and his rubrics are self explanatory.

He would have students turn in drafts and give very good feedback that made it easy to score well on the final copies. He would also change due dates if he had fallen behind in any capacity. It was a very low stress class with good, practical writing experience, and he was a very kind professor.

relatively easy english GE. he has drafts due for every assignment (automatic 10pts) to give feedback for when u submit the real thing. his grading is semi-hard but if u ask him questions he will tell u what to fix. the last part of the course is mainly a big group project so make sure u have a good group, its presentation, visual art, a long paper

Great professor. Funny, flamboyant, colorful, super caring. You'll never feel intimidated by him. Gives pretty simple feedback to your assignments, just do what he asks and it's both an easy A and an easy course credit. Group projects so be ready for that, but he's always eager to help. Would absolutely recommend.
A lot of works. Instructions are super unclear, so you may get lost on assignments. Lectures are super boring but short. Not an easy A for a writing GE 2367 class.

You can tell in lecture that kimo really cares about students. Hes a chill guy and offers a ton of opportunities to ask for help. Rubrics are vague, yes, but there are drafts for everything that give you 10 automatic points and he also gives exact feedback for the final draft. Not strict with deadlines and grades easy. Easy ge with minimal work!

Dr. Tichgelaar is a really caring guy. His rubrics are somewhat vague, but he gives great feedback on rough drafts so you know exactly what to do and its no issue. If you have a question, I would recommend office hours over emailing him to get a faster response. Overall awesome guy and awesome class. Great preparation for later in life. Take this!

Not complaining because the class is too difficult, its really easy if your keep up with the work, but the problem is that Tich gives very vague directions on how to complete assignments and then marks people off for missing out on stuff he never explained. He grades kinda tough as well and likes to knit pick on things.

He is a really good professor but my only catch is that the class is a lot of work for a GE, really only with the group project. It's much longer than it really needed to be and the asynchronous class content is extremely long and not very engaging. Would't take again but he isn't bad. Its mostly just how the class was structured and the project.

Class itself isn't any more fun than your other classes. Slightly more work than what you would expect in a GE course, but is still pretty easy. The group project can suck big time if your group doesn't help that much. Kimo is a pretty cool guy and is always willing to help when you need it. I would take this over the summer though. Save the stress

Interesting teacher but seemed very disorganized. Due dates are changed without notice and assignments are created sometimes without making it clear. Nonetheless, the stuff he teaches is pretty good for the most part, like the resumes, cover letters, and follow-up letters! There isn't too much work and it can usually get done without much effort!

- He is a very odd person. - Does not respond to emails until a week later. - He has assignments hidden from the Modules and Grades pages so you'd have to look at the To-Do list that's only on the Home Page, the little thing on the right when you click and he doesn't tell you about that anywhere in the course/class/syllabus.
Not understanding, very weird. Does not give clear instructions for assignments and response time for emails are very slow.

He's great. He dresses like he thinks he's doctor who, but he is a very funny and interesting person. Everything he taught was useful to the course or to our careers in general. You will like him. He grades pretty easily, but don't take that for granted- what you are learning has a good chance of being important to you at some point.
He's a great prof! He really prepared me for writing resumes and cover letters. His class is easy and you will learn a lot!

Professor Tichgelaar taught very well and this course is very useful (CV, Resume, Memo). The only thing I want to mention is that there are so many papers. We need to finish about 27 assignments in the whole semester. If you already have a heavy schedule, don't take him. If not, please take him. Soft grader & Helpful teacher!
lecture is long and boring. not clear

Kimo is the man. If you do all of the work the class is an easy A. You turn in a draft for each assignment and he gives you feedback. If you do what he says, you'll get an A. There are two major group projects, make sure you get with good people or you'll be doing a lot on your own. If you're ever confused, his office hours really help.

Odd dude, but friendly and helpful. Lots of busy work in the class, but nothing really hard. Few group projects to be wary of - try your best to get a good group.  Attendance is taken and skipping classes hurts your grade, so make sure to show up.
It's engr 2367, it is easy with any professor. Kim is the man. He has a very flamboyant personality  and a great sense of style. He alway seems enthusiastic to come to class. Would recomend

Jack is genuinely one of the best professors I have ever taken at Ohio State. His lectures can be long and be prepared to put in the work for presentations every single week. However, he truly cares, he's funny, and has amazing energy.
Had Jack for two courses back-to-back ISE 6801 and ENGR 6210. Great instructor, great person, genuinely cares that students learn what is being instructed.
You can tell he doesn't take life too serious. Attendance wasn't mandatory I literally showed up because he was just a cool guy and his class wasn't boring.
amazing

ISE 3800 really should not be a semester long. It is all very basic knowledge, and I really did not learn anything this semester. Tests are worded extremely poorly, causing people to get bad grades on very easy subject matter. To improve, I recommend that Jack take the GTA-created tests before giving them to students. They are awfully worded.

He is a very nice person--extremely personable. Material covered in class is straightforward and will be applicable in any professional context. The class is really easy if you've managed a project before. Exams are not well written, and a few students did badly on them even though the material covered in class is not particularly challenging.

Professor Slavinski was a nice and caring guy, but his tests were tricky even though they were on easy content. I bombed midterms, but would go into the GTA and get some points back. The professor cares about real world applications and not so much about grades. Attendance sheets are passed around at every lecture/lab.
Jack is awesome

Jack is a great professor. Getting a good grade is secondary to him to making sure you leave with something valuable. If you decide to go in and not be involved in the class and just pass, you're not going to get anything out of it. But if you decide to put forth some effort and get to know Jack he's a great connection to make and you learn lots.
Pretty easy grader, most of the stuff was common sense. Do the readings and you will get 100% on the quiz. I didn't do them but still got an A in the class

They need to figure this class out...it's a joke. All of the material covered in the course could essentially be covered in about 4-5 hours of lecture..but it's a whole semester. Shouldn't have studied for the final. Everything stemmed from basic knowledge but the questions were so poorly worded that you didn't know what was being asked anyway.
Good use of industry knowledge
Dr. Vines is really just ok. Her lectures are very boring but that comes with the FE classes. Helpful when needed but honestly the TA's usually were more knowledgeable.
Cannot call herself an instructor at all. Whatever the word completely opposite of instructing is, she wins it.
Great lecturer, super sweet and greatly helped with my understanding of coding (I had minimal experience before the class, the instructor offered a great foundation.)
Dr. Vines was very kind and genuinely cared for students success. The class is easy if you read the rubrics and turn in things on time.

Dr. Vines was one of the nicest instructors I've had. She was very helpful in her office hours and made a mandatory course I wasn't fond of a lot more enjoyable. I highly recommend taking the FE courses with her.
So strict on Graphic Assignments. Even my worst enemy in my life, I will not recommend him to take her class
Bad at teaching

She treats her students as if they are still in high school. She berates anyone who mutters a word in her class. High ego and does not care about the material she is "teaching". Choose anyone else for your own good.

Very condescending, very much held the vibe of "I am a doctor, and I am better than you" blatantly disrespected and talked down to a student with autism, blatantly disregarding them.  She would publicly embarrass you in front of the class if you talked while she was speaking even at a whisper level to your group mates.

Yes, he has an accent and some people think he's yelling at them, but it's just because he's passionate. He likes to answer your questions and will only lecture for 5 minutes each session then do practice problems which are pretty much what will be on the test. Great teacher, tests weren't bad if you do the homework and practice tests.
Funny guy, I'd imagine not sure though. I dropped out my second day in the class because of some horrible smelling heffer #freepalestine

Gilat lectures well, his midterms were fair, his final was difficult, but he curved the class afterward. His office hours are helpful, and while he comes off as demeaning, he does not mean it. His homeworks are much harder than midterms, so it prepares you well for them. I think his bad rep is undeserved, people who show up and study do well.

AVOID. Take this class anywhere else, do not interact with Amos Gilat at all. Nice guy, sure, but not good teacher. Tests are 88 percent of the class, they are WAY harder than the homework, and no other opportunities for extra credit. Our final grade average was 55. THAT IS FAILING. If the average student fails your class, retire.

Bad lecturer and even worse at setting up a class. All combined, the entire class came down to how you did on exactly 16 problems. Nice enough if you meet him outside of class, but still won't help you much. He means well, but still avoid him if at all possible.

Gilat was one of the worst lecturers I've ever had. His lectures only include solving problems, with little explanations as to why we solve them. There are only 4 grades in the entire class: 6 quizzes, 2 midterms and the final (44%). Refuses to curve, even when the midterm avgs were below 65%. Exams are lengthy/hard, he doesn't care if you pass.

Amos has some of the worst lectures at OSU, very hard to understand and most of the concepts require you to learn from YouTube. The class consists of 3 exams worth 88% of your grade. This concept alone should make anyone want to run away. When someone asks a question in class they are belittled. Worst experience Ive ever had. Avoid at all costs.

Don't take his course. You will only be graded on quizzes, midterms, and the final. The quizzes are worth 12% of your grade, midterms are 44% and the final is 44%. He is incredibly rude and will get upset if you ask a question that he doesn't think is a "good" question. He hates repeating anything and expects everything to come easy to everyone.

Avoid by any means necessary. Its a hard class but his teaching method makes it 10 times harder. It is example after example with little to no explanation behind his problem solving strategy. The final is hard and worth 44% of your grade which is outrageous. Unfortunately the worst experience I've had at OSU.

Professor Gilat doesn't teach you any of the material. He expects you to learn it on your own and he does practice problems in class. This method of teaching may work for some people but it doesn't for me. He is available outside of class and will answer your "good" questions, but if you ask a "bad" question you will get made fun of.
Not a bad person, but he is ignorant and kinda dont care how you do.
Terrible and old lecturer, doesn't put anything online and it really isn't worth going to lecture or recitation. HW takes a good 10 hours a week. Exams are all open book and fairly simple however.

1181 is just a semester long hot mess. If you have never programmed before, the MATLAB is a little confusing. The class just isn't structured very well for practicing and getting good at programming. Also, it's an "inverted" class which means you just go a lot of stupid work at home, in addition to homework, and quizzes before every class.

Professor Gilat seems nice, but has no interest in this course, as he mentioned multiples times throughout the semester. Requires you to buy 2 of his awfully written textbooks, in which you will realize wont help you much for the 10+ hours of homework a week. Advice for incoming students: be prepared to learn this course on your own.
He is a nice guy. If you go to office hours, ask him questions. He is a bit condescending, but he will answer questions and he knows the material well.
He will refuse to help during his office hours. He says he doesn't have time for you because he's too busy writing his text books. Terrible professor.

Made everything seem easy in class then I would struggle on homework and midterms, often not knowing what ideas to apply. The examples in class were helpful but it would have helped if he taught it in a way that we would know what concepts to apply depending on the problem statement and given information.
Gilat was awful at explaining things, does not give equation sheet on tests

I wish he was more clear explaining what his mindset is in solving problems. He does nothing but do example problems in class, which I liked. I found this class is immensely difficult. Doesn't provide or let you make an equations sheet, so have fun memorizing tons of equations instead of actually studying. Just terrible.
Terrible. Goes over a few simple examples in class that do not prepare you well for the exams or homework, both are very difficult. Take this course with Dr. Mokashi if you have the chance.

This class was terrible. I dont think i learned one thing the entire semester. The material is so bad so it's hard to say how he is as a teacher. Lectures are pointless but his exams are really easy due to the open book policy. Homeworks were very hard and long, and only time I had a problem and went to his office he refused to help me out.

Well, if you're ME you have to take this class and you probably have to take it with him too. Homework is awful, as everyone agrees, but his exams are OK as long as you have a good idea of how to do stuff. Lectures are a waste of time. This professor is AWESOME for FE series, but for the actual ME class it's a rough ride. doable though!

His lectures are an absolute waste of time.  The material in the class is very straight forward, but the exams do not reflect the material that was gone over in class or the HW.  HW takes 5+ hours a week, is graded very late, so you do not know your grade until it is too late. Try to avoid for  ME250

Gilat's teaching is purely from powerpoint presentations. Programming classes should not be taught in a classroom! We need lectures to be labs. He forces you to use his incomprehensible textbooks. Homework is tedious and takes at least 5 hours per week. All seems well until the final, get ready for complete failure.

you're forced to use his crappy text books which are hard to follow and full of typos. the class is basic math but you are forced to think think a computer on all homeworks and tests, and they take a while to complete. he isnt very articulate so it can be hard to understand him.

One of OSU's worst teachers. If you have prior experience with MATLAB and can teach yourself quickly, then you may be OK. Otherwise, it will be a battle. Fast-paced, entirely not enough time for homework assignments, which are graded without mercy. You are on your own in this class, I don't know exactly what tuition paid for with this class.

The whole class is matlab and numerical methods.The grading is very tough,not enough time for the tests,the homeworks was very hard.20%homework 35% midterm 45% final.What he does in class is going through the slides which is really close from the book.He didn't give review sheets or examples for the tests,he didn't clarify what the tests are.
Real laid back guy. Goes over slides quickly which leaves you plenty of time to do your work.

The worst professor at The Ohio State, he gives no partial credit, the only reason he teaches this class is so you have to buy his book, you dont have to go be cause he reads straight out of the book, if you do go take a pillow.
He seemed uninterested at times. Although it's useful at TIMES, he swears by his MATLAB book (I think he just wants your moneys?). I did mediocre on the exams and still managed to get an A-
Funny guy.  Kept lectures short and sweet.  Made fun of the program's slides and made to sure to avoid confusing us.  Great professor, made 183 a breeze(not that its not easy already)
He was a pretty sweet teacher.  He keeps lectures short and sweet, but sticks around to help students 1 on 1.  He is pretty funny, but has a mild accent that isn't too bad.
Great teacher.  Was always available for guidance whether it was for the class or just life in general.  He just wanted to see his students succeed.
pointless class, homework a complete waste of time

awesome professor. Helpful and intrested in helping students succeed. Class is way too long but he tries to make it fun. Both the matlab book and numerical methods books are really good. Fair tests, hard homeworks at time, but you learn alot.
Explains things well, even if it takes a bit to hear what he's saying through his accent.  His book explains exactly what to do, homework takes a while but is never too hard.
He knows the Numerical Methods material he is teaching. He explains the code a bit too slowly for my tastes, but there are some folks who it's a good pace for.

wow...ummm way too much homework for only 10% of your grade...so your midterm and final are worth 90% of your grade...awesome....class is useless...i just  printed the notes offline and taught myself...dont buy the book...just mooch off of someone else when you rarely need it....overall...this class=worthless
No Comments

He's really into his research. With some professors, this can be a problem, but with Gilat, just talk to him about his research once or twice and he will become more interested in helping you out and seeing you succeed. Plus, he wrote the MATLAB book; I mean, seriously, who else could teach it better?
Hardly cared to teach or help students in my class.  He wrote the book on Malab, but refuses to help students with it at all.
Accent gets in the way sometime, but he wrote the book on MATLAB and there is no better person to talk to about it. He'll teach you to program so well in MATLAB you'll wanna use it for everything.
Helps he wrote the MATlab book
He is down to earth and seem to understand the student's thought.  Fairly flexible and available to  help.  Sometimes funny but his accent make what he said so serious.
Has a slovic accent but usually dont have any trouble understanding him. Not very hard, but it was a very easy course. Seemed willing to help. Has a light sense of humor and keeps things interesting
I had him as a lab instructor.  The lecture can be boring, but he's a very helpful teacher and makes the class interesting.
An accent, but you can still understand him.  He knows English very well but phrases he's used sometimes have made me crack up.  Very funny, helpful, and knows what he is talking about.
No Comments
No Comments
Funny and interesting! Makes class 10 times better!

GOAT- I loved being in his class. He knew how to explain tough topics with simple analogies that you could remember in exams. He knows how to break down the topics and explain. Exams were strictly explaining topics, no computations. Just an all around great guy 100000/10. made Semiconductors an EASY topic.

Professor Paul Berger excels at teaching the fundamental concepts of physics devices rather than focusing on numbers. Be prepared for exams that require extensive preparation and a lot of writing. Also, not punctual!
However, he assigns minimal homework and provides opportunities to improve your grades, even if you struggle on the early exams.

S.S.Electronics is already an abstract concept & Berger does its best at explaining it with analogies & everyday life examples. No math in tests but homework is a bit weird because we don't use numbers and equations during lectures. Be prepared to take *a lot* of notes during class. Go to the exam reviews (!!!!) he'll tell you what to expect.

Dr. Berger expects you to be able to explain clearly how everything works. His exams and lectures are about the device physics and less about the equations behind them. Homework can be brutal because of the lack of math taught in class. Exams are all about drawing band diagrams and using analogies to explain device physics. Hard but rewarding class

Dr. Berger has great lectures and tries to emphasize the fundamental concepts rather than the math. Tests ask for you to write out the concepts behind electronic devices instead of math.
